page.title: 04LANDSCAPE
page.content: A level plain draining gradually into a river is not of itself dramatic, but the variety of trees and well-weathered brick and black and white housees ensure that the general aspect is pleasing to the eye. The trees and woods are mostly deciduous but there are some confiers and holly. Elms no longer survive but Oak, Ash and Sycamore abound, and most houses have decorative trees - Copper Beech, Yews, Laburnum and Rowan as well as fruit trees. The river banks offer, by way of contrast, Willow, Alder and Sedge Willow. Spraying has reduced the variety of wayside and meadow flowers, but Spring and Summer produce Lesser Celandine, Meadowsweet, Campion, Honeysuckle and Wild Roses.
